headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Carlos Baleba update, third kit out, Alejandro Garnacho link
body: Hello and welcome to your dedicated Manchester United transfers blog on Wednesday, August 13.
Heading into the final few weeks of the summer transfer window, United remain active and open to pursuing new opportunities. One of the latest names linked is Carlos Baleba of Brighton & Hove Albion.

The young midfielder is considered one of the most highly rated prospects in European football, with a sky-high ceiling. So far, the club have added Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo, Diego Leon and Benjamin Sesko to their ranks.

Ruben Amorim’s side wrapped up their pre-season campaign over the weekend with a 1-1 draw against Fiorentina at Old Trafford, going on to win the match in a penalty shootout. Now, the focus shifts to the start of the Premier League season and Sunday afternoon's clash with Arsenal.

However, despite the significant investment in three high-profile attacking signings, further business could still be on the cards - provided United are able to sanction one or two departures. As for potential outgoings, Tyrell Malacia, Antony, Jadon Sancho, and Alejandro Garnacho are all effectively available for transfer.
Catch up with the latest news, views and Manchester United transfer rumours below.
According to Fabrizio Romano, contact with Brighton for the midfielder has continued from Manchester United's side.

Speaking on his YouTube channel last night, he said: "Contacts continue for Carlos Baleba. Today, Man United spoke again to the agents of the player. They are prepared to try to understand how much Brighton want.

"So this week, I expect Manchester United to try to understand the situation directly with Brighton, and let’s see what’s going to happen there. But Baleba remains a topic at United. They are still not moving on another midfielder, and it means that United maintain the contacts active for Baleba and also try to understand if they can really make it happen or if it’s going to be impossible because Brighton still have no intention to reduce their price tag."
Give Me Sport report that Man United are keeping an eye on England international, Kane.

The 32-year-old, who joined Bayern Munich from Tottenham Hotspur in 2023, has a release clause in his contract which will come into play in January 2026 and could see him leave the Bundesliga champions for as little as £56million.
Manchester City have reportedly agreed personal terms with Paris Saint-Germain goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma over a move to the Etihad.

The 26-year-old Italy international has been linked with a move to the Premier League after he was deemed surplus to requirements at the Parc des Princes under Luis Enrique. United were one of the Premier League clubs most frequently linked with a move for Donnarumma, though it seems that bitter rivals City are now looking to strike a move for the shot-stopper.
French publication L'Equipe claims that Donnarumma had been in talks with both United and City but it is the latter who have reached an agreement on personal terms with the former AC Milan prodigy.

We'll be keeping you updated throughout the day with the latest United news, as there are now less than three weeks until the summer transfer window closes. The countdown is also on for the Reds' Premier League opener against Arsenal!
So, grab yourself a brew - let's get started, shall we?
Join us tomorrow for all the latest Manchester United transfer news and rumours.
See you then!

Paris Saint-Germain goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma, who has been linked with a move to Manchester United this summer, has issued a statement on his future after being left out of Luis Enrique’s squad for the UEFA Super Cup final against Tottenham on Wednesday.
The Italy international has one year remaining on his contract at the Parc des Princes and has been tipped to leave the club this summer.

Donnarumma’s future in the French capital appears untenable, and his recent statement reads like a farewell to the club and its supporters, strongly suggesting that the decision to leave may not have been his own.
Read what he had to say here.
Manchester United remain confident of selling Rasmus Hojlund before the summer transfer window closes, writes James Quinlan.
A hint to what life could be like at Old Trafford for Hojlund following those three signings came last Saturday too, when he was an unused substitute in 1-1 friendly draw with Fiorentina.
The club have already judged around £30m to be a fair market value for a striker who last season scored only four Premier League goals in 32 outings.
However, the CIES Football Observatory has freshly updated its estimated transfer values and would suggest United are severely underestimating themselves and their Danish international.
Read the story here.
David de Gea had a heartwarming interaction with Bruno Fernandes' children after Manchester United's pre-season friendly against Fiorentina over the weekend, writes Keifer MacDonald.
The Reds drew 1-1 with the Serie A outfit at Old Trafford on Saturday afternoon after Simon Sohm's eighth-minute opener was cancelled out by a Robin Gosens own-goal.
For De Gea, it was his first return to Old Trafford since he left United at the end of his contract in May 2023. The Spaniard spent 12 seasons with the Red Devils, making 545 appearances.
Read the story here.
Manchester United are not actively pursuing Paris Saint-Germain outcast Gianluigi Donnarumma, according to reports.

The goalkeeper has one year remaining on his deal at the Parc des Princes and could depart for a reduced fee this summer. He has not been included in Luis Enrique's squad for their UEFA Super Cup meeting with Tottenham on Wednesday night amid ongoing speculation over his future.
The Italian has been linked with a switch to the Premier League, although the Daily Mail claim United have shut down any suggestions he is a target for Ruben Amorim's side.
Donnarumma is not a target and goalkeeper is not a priority position for the club this summer.
Manchester United midfielder Toby Collyer is in talks over a loan move to Championship side Hull City, according to the Daily Mail.
The article claims initial talks have been held over a season-long loan for the 21-year-old, with the Tigers having a strong track record of devloping young talent.
It has been suggested talks are at an early stage and there remains some competition from Sheffield Wednesday, but the midfielder is open to a loan switch ahead of the new campaign.
Garnacho joining Chelsea on a permanent deal could help Man United fund a swoop for Baleba and, also, hand the midfielder a dream welcome gift.

Baleba appears to be open to an Old Trafford switch, but it seems very likely available (or unavailable) finances will be what prevents a would-be deal. Elsewhere, United are said to want £50million to sell Garnacho, but Chelsea are not currently keen on hitting that figure.

If a compromise is reached on a fee, it seems almost guaranteed that United will put those funds towards signing Baleba. If that scenario does play out, United's latest arrival could be left the perfect welcome gift by the departing Garnacho. That is because both players wore the No.17 shirt last season and Garnacho moving on would leave that free for Baleba to take.

As potential alternatives, Baleba has also worn No.20 and No.35 but - after a few alterations - only the former is available at United. It certainly seems as though the No.17 would be his first-choice considering he changed to that squad number at the start of his second season at Brighton.
Man United have made an unusual Rasmus Hojlund decision after launching their new third kit for the upcoming Premier League season.

The smart design is likely to go down a treat with supporters as the predominantly black kit includes a yellow and blue trim. The Adidas strip was unveiled to the general public on Tuesday morning and while there was not anything overtly unusual about the launch, the Dane's involvement may raise eyebrows.
MEN Sport reported this week that the striker was now open to the possibility of signing for AC Milan.

Throughout the summer, Hojlund had insisted that he saw his future at Old Trafford and was not interested in looking at other challenges. However, following the arrival of Benjamin Sesko last week, that mindset has now changed.
Exactly whether the deal will be permanent or on loan is unclear. If United were to allow Hojlund to leave permanently, they would be looking for a price tag in the region of £30m.
Slovenia coach Matjaz Kek has closely followed Sesko’s progress over the past four years and knows exactly what the striker brings to Man United.
"From time to time, I have to stop him a bit and calm him down: it's just the amazing energy [that he has]," Kek told Italian reporters ahead of Euro 2024.

"He is like a magnet, and such a positive one. It is clear that his likeability and splendid public appearances are making it known to little boys and girls that there is a lot of work, training, and sacrifices behind this [success]. He is the modern striker par excellence. I don't know where he will play next season, he will decide but, for now, I'll enjoy him this summer.

"We're talking about a physically strong centre-forward who has made great progress, also technically, month after month. He came to [the national team] when he was just a lad: a 17-year-old boy, and since then I have been watching him grow into a man. He has become a very important part of the team.
"Despite his youthfulness, he carries a sort of energy - the character of a diligent boy who would train day and night to achieve his goal."
Manchester United were one of three clubs to make an approach for Fiorentina centre-back Comuzzo, according to Tutto Sport.
The report claims that several sides have expressed interest in the young defender in recent weeks, with Bournemouth and Southampton also making moves.

Fiorentina owner and president Rocco Benito Commisso is said to be a strong admirer of Comuzzo and has rejected all three approaches. The club remain firmly opposed to selling, with Commisso convinced the youngster has a very bright future.
According to a report from La Gazzetta dello Sport, Inter Milan aim to capitalize on the ongoing fallout between Jadon Sancho and Manchester United in a bid to sign him this summer.

Inter, having decided to sign a forward this month, have added Sancho, Chelsea’s Christopher Nkunku, and Ademola Lookman to their target list. However, with Lookman reportedly commanding a hefty price, ‘all eyes’ are now on Sancho this summer.
Speaking to reports, Real Betis' sporting director Manu Fajardo has expressed his desire to sign Antony this summer.
He explained:
The desire on both sides, player and club, is to be together again. Every day that passes, the hope grows, but if Antony arrives, it's because he's doing so in the numbers that suit Betis.
Antony requested to leave United at the start of the summer.
Hurzeler maintains he has no 'fear' of losing key players, even with Baleba the latest high-profile name linked to a potential departure.
"No chance. I don’t feel fear," Hurzeler told the BBC. "I’m not afraid of anything because the only thing we can do is be the best version we can be every day, work as hard as we can.

"All the other things we can’t influence, so we really have to focus on us. For sure, we can’t spend the money like the big teams, but one of our biggest values is togetherness. And if you stay together, if we try to push our limits and increase the boundaries, then I’m sure we can compete with the big teams."

Hurzeler continued: "It’s not easy, but we proved last season that we are a very competitive team. Without Joao Pedro, for sure, he was an unbelievable player. But we can’t replace him with one player, we can replace him as a team. And that’s our focus."
Former Italy manager Arrigo Sacchi has questioned Hojlund's hesitation to leave Man United despite interest from AC Milan.

"We’re not talking about van Basten, nor are we talking about one of the strongest centre-forwards in Europe at the moment. He’s a decent player, nothing more," Sacchi told La Gazzetta dello Sport. "I understand the desire of the Rossoneri directors given that there is a shortage of strikers.

"But it has to be one that wants to come to Italy, one that doesn’t throw a tantrum. I don’t understand his choice. If Milan calls you, you pack your bags and get on the first plane to Malpensa. Milan, in the world of football, is a mystical name. I, along with all the players who are brought in, would take a tour of the trophy room so that we understand where we have come.

"Of course, Manchester United is also a legendary team. But on the one hand, there is a club, Milan, which is offering you a permanent job, and on the other hand, there is a club that is doing everything to try and sell you. What would you choose?’
According to The Athletic, United's squad are beginning to rally around to try and help the Reds sign Carlos Baleba this summer.
It is claimed that unnamed players have contacted the midfielder to explain the set-up at United.
Onana and Mbeumo both represent Cameroon with Baleba while the midfielder knows Leny Yoro from their time together at Lille.
Despite Brighton's stance that Baleba is not for sale this summer, their manager Fabian Hurzeler has insisted that he is not fearful of losing their better players in the transfer window.
Brighton have already lost the likes of Joao Pedro in this window.
He told the Monday Night Club:

We as a club always find solutions and I'm sure in the future we will find solutions. That's our model, we have to accept it. I think that as a club we have proved we are not only selling big players. We have had offers for other players - big offers for [Kaoru] Mitoma and other players. We proved that we are not selling every player. Of course there were some big players who left the club, but there are new players that are coming into the club. With the togetherness we have, with the team chemistry we have, we can compete with the big teams, and we can compete with teams who might be individually better than us.

So much focus has been on attacking quarters this summer that very few names have done the rounds in other positions. Although the Bayern Munich man is a fine player in his own right, surely United are stocked-up at the back? One to keep an eye on, even if it seems fanciful at this stage;

United have also been linked with a move for Donnarumma this summer and Chelsea's stance comes after PSG left the goalkeeper out of their squad for the Super Cup on Wednesday.

headline: Injury boost, three debuts - Manchester United's strongest matchday squad vs Arsenal
body: The countdown to the start of the new Premier League season is almost over.
Less than 48 hours after Liverpool and Bournemouth open the 2025/26 campaign at Anfield on Friday night, Manchester United and Arsenal will take centre stage at Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon.
The visit of the Londoners will mark the beginning of Ruben Amorim's first full season as United head coach, and there is an upbeat mood surrounding the club heading into their season opener.

A successful summer transfer window, which has seen four new arrivals, and a positive pre-season campaign means United supporters will be arriving at Old Trafford on confident last season's woes will be banished.
But what could Amorim's matchday squad for the season opener look like?

If Onana wins his fitness battle and gets the green light to start, it will be interesting to see the landscape of the back three he is tasked with marshalling. Leny Yoro is a guaranteed starter after starting four of United's five friendlies, but there is less certainty about who will join him in defence.
Matthijs de Ligt and Harry Maguire are competing to start in the middle of the back three and Ayden Heaven is rivalling Luke Shaw to start as the left-sided centre-back.

All four players will believe they are worthy of starting berths, leaving Amorim with a selection dilemma to solve. There is no obvious answer, but De Ligt and Shaw could get the nod after making three starts each during the summer.

Amad and Patrick Dorgu are shoo-ins to occupy the two wing-back positions. The latter came on in leaps and bounds during pre-season, particularly during the tour of the United States, while Amad started all five warm up matches.
Bruno Fernandes is set to occupy one of the two midfield positions. The United captain has regularly flexed his muscles in the engine room and is a guaranteed starter.

However, there is an ongoing debate about who should partner the Portuguese international. Manuel Ugarte, Kobbie Mainoo and Casemiro are the contenders and they all got opportunities to prove their worth during pre-season.

In an ideal world, United will bring in a new midfielder before the transfer window slams shut, but that mission is unlikely to be fulfilled ahead of Sunday's game. It means Ugarte, amid his defensive profile, is the most logical partner for Fernandes.

Mainoo will believe he is worthy of a starting berth, but he is a forward-thinking player, meaning the prospect of him partnering Fernandes in the centre of midfield would risk leaving United vulnerable to opposition attacks.
Cunha, who scored 17 goals for Wolves last season, should start as the left-sided No.10. Bryan Mbeumo is the obvious pick to fill the other No.10 spot.

Despite only featuring twice in pre-season due to a lack of match sharpness, Mbeumo impressed against both Everton and Fiorentina. He linked up really well with Amad and should be awarded his competitive debut for United from the start.
Supported by Cunha and Mbeumo, Benjamin Sesko should come straight into the team and lead the attack. He arrived from RB Leipzig last weekend to provide the final piece in the attacking jigsaw.

As far as the bench is concerned, Amorim has a competitive squad at his disposal, meaning he will have options to turn to. Tom Heaton had a better pre-season than Altay Bayindir and should be promoted to second-choice in the pecking order.
Defensive cover can come from Diogo Dalot, Maguire and Heaven. Mainoo and Casemiro can offer midfield cover and Mason Mount will be able to offer support to Cunha and Mbeumo in the No.10 position.
Unless an exit materialises beforehand, Hojlund should make the bench. Chido Obi should also make the matchday squad against his former club.
United starting XI: Onana; Yoro, De Ligt, Shaw; Amad, Ugarte, Fernandes, Dorgu; Mbeumo, Cunha; Sesko.
United substitutes: Heaton, Dalot, Maguire, Heaven, Mainoo, Casemiro, Mount, Hojlund, Obi.

headline: Manchester United need Carlos Baleba to prove Ruben Amorim right again in the transfer window
body: With just under three weeks of the summer transfer window remaining Manchester United face a race against time to get their shopping done.
United have drafted in four new faces so far this summer, bringing in Diego Leon, Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and most recently Benjamin Sesko.
The additions of Cunha, Mbeumo and Sesko are statement signings that should transform United's attack. Suddenly, last season's biggest weakness looks like being this season's biggest strength.

Although United found the signing of Cunha a simple deal to complete given the £62.5million release clause he had in his Wolves contract, the deals to bring Mbeumo and Sesko to Old Trafford were not quite as smooth.

United spent several weeks locked in discussions with Brentford to sign Mbeumo and they faced stiff competition from Newcastle United for Sesko. However, both players shared the same ambition: they wanted to join United.

Mbeumo, who was also linked with Newcastle, made it clear to Brentford's hierarchy long before United reached a breakthrough in negotiations that his preferred destination this summer was Old Trafford. Sesko, too, set his sights on a move to M16.

Having failed to qualify for any form of European football this season, concerns were raised about whether United would find it difficult to attract players who would not look out of place in the Champions League. However, just as head coach Ruben Amorim stated back in April, United will always appeal to players.
He said: "It's Manchester United. What I feel is that there's a lot of players that want to play for our club.

"I know that if you look at our club at the moment it looks like sometimes with all the problems with the staff, people going, changing coach, the results, it looks like a little bit of a problem at the moment. But we have a clear idea.
"That is the easiest part to explain to a player. And then it's Manchester United. Everybody wants to play for Manchester United."

In Cunha, Mbeumo and Sesko, United have recruited three players who scored 58 goals between them last season. They could have quite easily ended up at clubs who could have offered them Champions League football this term.

Instead, they wanted to move to Old Trafford, attracted to the size and the scale of one of the world's biggest clubs. United will now be hoping Brighton & Hove Albion ace Carlos Baleba subscribes to the same thinking.

United remain keen to strengthen their midfield options ahead of the window closing and Baleba is on their radar. He is one of European football's most highly-rated midfielders and his ceiling is sky-high.

Like Cunha, Mbeumo and Sesko, he would not look out of place in a team playing Champions League football this season. He can do a little bit of everything in midfield and his skillset is very attractive.

With United's midfield in desperate need of fresh blood, the club's hierarchy will be hoping Baleba is the latest player to prove Amorim right and be attracted to the prospect of representing the Reds.

body: Manchester United will return to Premier League action this weekend when they welcome Arsenal to Old Trafford.
After an underwhelming 17th-place finish last season, the Reds know a strong start is important if they are to enjoy a better campaign this time around.
It will, however, be a different United side that lines up at Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon, with Ruben Amorim adding new faces such as Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Benjamin Sesko to his ranks.
But you already knew that, didn't you?

The 26-year-old Italy international has been linked with a move to the Premier League after he was deemed surplus to requirements at the Parc des Princes under Luis Enrique.
United were one of the Premier League clubs most frequently linked with a move for Donnarumma, though it seems that bitter rivals City are now looking to strike a move for the shot-stopper.
French publication L'Equipe claims that Donnarumma had been in talks with both United and City but it is the latter who have reached an agreement on personal terms with the former AC Milan prodigy.

MEN says: If reports are true and City have agreed a deal with Donnarumma, then it would be a bitter blow for United, because although the Italy international continues to divide opinion, he was a key pillar of the PSG side that won the Champions League and Ligue 1 title last term.
His experience of winning some of the biggest trophies in club football would be a welcome addition to Old Trafford for Amorim.

The 32-year-old, who joined Bayern Munich from Tottenham Hotspur in 2023, has a release clause in his contract which will come into play in January 2026 and could see him leave the Bundesliga champions for as little as £56m.
Kane, who won his first major trophy earlier this season, has two years remaining on his current deal.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund value to Man United clear as striker transfer timeline emerges
body: Manchester United remain confident of selling Rasmus Hojlund before the summer transfer window closes.
Ruben Amorim, therefore, has a new-look front three in place for the start of the new Premier League campaign as Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo were brought in earlier this summer.
A hint to what life could be like at Old Trafford for Hojlund following those three signings came last Saturday too, when he was an unused substitute in 1-1 friendly draw with Fiorentina.
So, United feel the time is right to try and cash in on a player who only two summers ago cost them £72m.
The club have already judged around £30m to be a fair market value for a striker who last season scored only four Premier League goals in 32 outings.
However, the CIES Football Observatory has freshly updated its estimated transfer values and would suggest United are severely underestimating themselves and their Danish international.
The Switzerland-based study uses a statistical model to estimate a player's value and considers factors such as player performance, age, contract length, international status and the level they play.
And they reckon Hojlund is actually worth between £57.8m and £66.4m (€67m and €77m).
What the CIES algorithm may not consider is the immediacy of the situation. United have less than three weeks to seal an exit for the 22-year-old and options will be limited.

Hojlund himself is known to be open to joining Serie A giants AC Milan, who have started to rebuild under returning manager Massimiliano Allegri after failing to qualify for European football this coming season.
At this stage it is unclear whether a permanent deal will be struck or if a loan will have to be a temporary solution.
According to La Gazzetta dello Sport, Milan are placing priority on fixing their defence before putting any effort into signing Hojlund.
They are actively working on the signings of Zachary Athekame from BSC Young Boys and Koni de Winter from Genoa. Negotiations are also advancing to allow Malick Thiaw to join Newcastle United.

headline: Gianluigi Donnarumma issues statement on PSG exile amid Manchester United transfer speculation
body: Paris Saint-Germain goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma, who has been linked with a move to Manchester United this summer, has issued a statement on his future after being left out of Luis Enrique’s squad for the UEFA Super Cup final against Tottenham on Wednesday.

The Italy international has one year remaining on his contract at the Parc des Princes and has been tipped to leave the club this summer. PSG have already signed Lucas Chevalier from Ligue 1 rivals Lille, and the Frenchman is expected to assume the starting role for the new season.

United are among several European clubs to have been linked with the 26-year-old, as doubts continue to grow over his future at PSG. However, a recent report from the Daily Mail suggests that a goalkeeper is not currently a priority for the Manchester club, and talk of interest in the PSG outcast has been played down.

That said, Donnarumma’s future in the French capital appears untenable, and his recent statement reads like a farewell to the club and its supporters, strongly suggesting that the decision to leave may not have been his own. "To the special Paris fans," he wrote.

"From the first day I arrived, I gave everything – on and off the pitch – to earn my place and defend the goal of Paris Saint-Germain. Unfortunately, someone has decided that I can no longer be part of the group and contribute to the team’s success. I am disappointed and disheartened.

"I hope to have the opportunity to look the fans at the Parc des Princes in the eyes one more time and say goodbye as it should be done. If that doesn’t happen, I want you to know that your support and affection mean the world to me, and I will never forget it.

"I will always carry with me the memory of all the emotions, the magical nights, and of you, who made me feel at home. To my teammates – my second family – thank you for every battle, every laugh, every moment we shared. You will always be my brothers.
"Playing for this club and living in this city has been an immense honour. Thank you, Paris."

headline: PSG boss explains Gianluigi Donnarumma decision amid Man City and Man United transfer rumours
body: Paris Saint-Germain manager Luis Enrique has taken responsibility for the decision to dismiss Gianluigi Donnarumma from his squad for the UEFA Super Cup. The goalkeeper has subsequently been linked with a transfer to either Manchester City or Manchester United.

Champions League winners PSG take on Tottenham Hotspur for the Super Cup in Italy on Wednesday night but have chosen to not include their first-choice goalkeeper of four years. Donnarumma's contract in the French capital expires at the end of the coming season, meaning he would become a free agent and able to depart without a transfer fee.
Tension has grown over the unresolved situation and now Enrique has confirmed it is he who has taken action.
"These are difficult decisions, but I take responsibility for the choice I made. If they were easy, anyone would make them. They have to do with the profile of the goalkeeper my team needs."
Stepping in for the Italian international is PSG's new signing Lucas Chevalier, who was bought from LOSC Lille for a reported €40m (£34.5m) last week.
According to RMC Sport, Donnarumma is City's top pick to replace Ederson should the Brazilian opt to leave the Etihad Stadium after eight years. Turkish media have reported interest from Galatasaray.
Also speaking on the topic of Donnarumma was PSG captain Marquinhos. The defender said: "We know how football is, which is a bit difficult, especially in the transfer market.
"He was a great player for us, he deserves all the best in his life. He's a great person and a great man, he respected this club a lot, but football is like that and sometimes we can't do too much.
"We don't know what happened in the discussion. I've been here for 12 or 13 years and I've experienced many moments like this: friends who arrive and friends who leave."

headline: Carlos Baleba among six transfers Man United could complete before Arsenal clash

United host Arsenal at Old Trafford on Sunday in their first competitive match of the new season. Ruben Amorim and Co. go into the new campaign on the back of an impressive pre-season trip to the United States and a penalty shootout win over Fiorentina at the weekend.

It's also been a busy summer on the transfer front for United, with three new signings being confirmed already. United have also sanctioned some departures this summer, with Marcus Rashford leaving to join Barcelona on loan. More players could leave Old Trafford before the September 1 deadline, with the potential for some deals to be completed before the clash against Arsenal arrives on Sunday.

In terms of new signings, the one player who is being linked with a move to United the most is Carlos Baleba. The Brighton midfielder has emerged as a target for United this summer, but it remains to be seen if a deal will be agreed with the Seagulls.

There have been reports that Brighton would demand around £100million, or more, to allow Baleba to leave the club this summer. While unlikely, there is still the possibility that a deal could be done over the next week if United wish to do so.

Alejandro Garnacho could also leave United this week amid reported interest from Chelsea. There could also be resolutions to Antony, Jadon Sancho and Tyrell Malacia's futures after the trio informed United of their desire to leave the club earlier in the summer.

headline: Antony's private meeting with new Manchester United signing amid transfer exit wait
body: Antony has spent some time with fellow Brazilian Matheus Cunha privately as his future appears to lie away from Manchester United.

Antony spent the second half of the season at Real Betis, where he enjoyed a career revival. He recorded as many assists for the Seville club (five) as he had in 70 more appearances for United, instantly endearing himself to the La Liga side's supporters.

He also helped Real Betis to reach the Conference League final as he later returned to Manchester, informing the club of his decision. Unsurprisingly, his former loan club re-joined the race to sign him, though they are reportedly only prepared to take him back on loan.
While training away from the main United squad, Antony spent time with Cunha, last weekend, after the latter's £62.5million move from Wolves earlier this summer.
On Sunday, Brazil celebrated Father's Day, and Antony appears to have spent the occasion with his family as well as Cunha's.
Taking to Instagram, the Brazilian winger wrote: "Dinner was really good. Thanks for the laughs and the chats.
"Chef Mauro Johnson, dinner was excellent. Thanks for dinner my brother Matheus Cunha - love you."

Antony's future remains undecided after spending last season on loan at Real Betis. He's been linked with Bayer Leverkusen - now managed by ex-United head coach Erik ten Hag - Juventus and a possible return to Real Betis.

headline: Man United Carlos Baleba transfer alternative would be dream signing for Sir Alex Ferguson
body: Manchester United know they're a midfielder away from having a hugely competitive starting XI after addressing some key flaws in their squad. The arrivals of Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko have given Ruben Amorim a completely new-look starting front three.

They'll need time to bed into their new surroundings at Old Trafford, but the general consensus is they're ready-made signings who can have an instant impact. United will want to avoid a repeat of last season's dismal campaign and the signing of a defensive midfielder could play a major part in that.

Given there'll be no European football for United this season, they can focus on the Premier League and winning some domestic silverware. Recent transfer speculation linking the club with Brighton midfielder Carlos Baleba are exciting links.

The club is crying out for a holding midfielder who can protect the back three and stop the XI being so vulnerable in transition. However, given Brighton have slapped a reported £100million asking price on the Cameroonian's head, the club know they need to offload a number of fringe players before investing that kind of money.
United's transfer spend already exceeds £200million and spending that much on one player would be a huge commitment. Which is why Adam Wharton would be a brilliant alternative signing.

Of course, Palace themselves would want a huge transfer fee, previously valued at around £60million. It's fair to say that his value is only going to increase after shining in the FA Cup-winning run last season and more recently in the Community Shield triumph over Liverpool.

CIES Football Observatory, who use a sample of more than 8,000 past transfers, the website evaluates prices of players from the five major European top-flights using the statistical technique of multiple linear regression - with fees paid by clubs as an independent variable, believe the former Blackburn Rovers player should be valued more in the region of €32million (£27.7m) to €37m (£32m).
Even if United have to pay in excess of £60million, that should be considered a bargain for one of Europe's top midfielders and a rising star in English football.

The current United ownership have stressed the importance of not making similar mistakes in the transfer market, given their torrid fall from grace. And yet, taking inspiration from the Sir Alex Ferguson era at Old Trafford could see them restore their place at England's top table.
Under Ferguson, United would have the best of English talents - Wayne Rooney, Rio Ferdinand, Paul Scholes, Michael Carrick. Wharton has the potential to be right among that calibre of players.

Also just 21-years-old, his best years are ahead of him and if continues to perform as he has for Palace, it's only a matter of time before a top club comes calling. Manchester United should be at the front of the queue.

headline: Mikel Arteta confirms Arsenal injury boost ahead of Manchester United fixture
body: Arsenal head coach Mikel Arteta has confirmed he expects attacker Leandro Trossard to be available for Sunday's Premier League opener against Manchester United at Old Trafford.
Trossard missed both of Arsenal's final two pre-season friendlies after sustaining a groin injury in their 1-0 defeat to Tottenham Hotspur during their pre-season tour of Singapore and Hong Kong.

After missing the Gunners' 3-2 defeat to Villarreal at the Emirates Stadium last Wednesday, some supporters were hopeful of seeing the Belgian back in action for Saturday's 3-0 win over Athletic Club.
However, he was again absent from the matchday squad, sparking fears he could miss the Premier League curtain-raiser at Old Trafford.

Arteta, though, is confident he will be in contention to make the squad for the clash with United, explaining: "I think he's going to be [okay] in a few days, yes, a little niggle in the groin. But he should be fine."
Trossard featured in all three of Arsenal's tour friendlies, starting the 3-2 win over Newcastle United and coming off the bench against both AC Milan and Tottenham.

The 30-year-old, who joined Arsenal from Brighton & Hove Albion in 2023, was a regular fixture for the Londoners last season, making 56 appearances across all competitions, chipping in with 10 goals and 10 assists.
Trossard scored the winner for Arsenal when they won 1-0 at Old Trafford in the Premier League in May last year.
Elsewhere, the only other injury concern playing on Arteta's mind ahead of the trip to M16 is Gabriel Jesus, who has not played since January and remains a long-term absentee.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United drop hint on permanent first-team promotion
body: Manchester United summer signing Diego Leon continues to train with the first-team.

United agreed a £3.3million fee, rising to £7m with add-ons, with Paraguay club Cerro Porteno to sign Leon, who was due to be assessed throughout pre-season before a decision was made on his next steps.
The options of playing for the Under-21s or going out on loan were considered, but the current indicators suggest that Leon will contribute to United's first-team squad this season.

Leon made a strong first impression at Carrington and was handed a first-team squad number (30) before the opening pre-season friendly against Leeds in Stockholm. Ruben Amorim started Leon in that friendly and he made substitute appearances against West Ham and Bournemouth in the United States.
The 18-year-old has now switched squad number, changing to No.35, with Benjamin Sesko expected to inherit his former number, but that does not mean Leon has been demoted.
Leon was formally introduced at Old Trafford alongside Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Sesko before the Fiorentina friendly on Saturday, further pointing to a first-team role.
He was an unused substitute and is understood to have trained with the first-team again on Sunday, as the players who were not involved against Fiorentina trained at Carrington on the following day.
When Leon spoke to journalists in Paraguay before his arrival in Manchester, he promised to "kill it" in pre-season to impress Amorim.
Leon has also impressed his teammates and Patrick Dorgu praised him after facing Leeds in Stockholm.

"He's a top, top player," said Dorgu. "He's a good player, he's good for everyone. Everyone has competition in their positions. Every player has two or three players in their position. It's just going to help the team even more. Everyone's going to be on their toes, everyone's going to give 100 per cent to the team."
Leon completed a medical to finalise his move from Cerro Porteno in January, but the deal outlined that he would move to Old Trafford in the summer transfer window.

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Spurs to hijack Arsenal target, Liverpool step up Guehi pursuit
body: Eberechi Eze could be heading to north London but not to Arsenal, while Liverpool have agreed personal terms with a Premier League captain.
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🔼 Cole Palmer – Chelsea to Manchester City
All signs point to this being utter horse sh*t, but with these two clubs, you never quite know. Chelsea would sell if the deal was right because business, and City have form for doing daft things. But surely even they wouldn’t do £200million-plus-£50million for a player they sold for £40million two years ago.

19) Rodrygo – Real Madrid to Manchester City
With Grealish gone and interest in Savinho, we could see this happening. And it’s great news for Real, with City, Liverpool and Arsenal threatening a bidding war that didn’t look likely at the start of the summer.

18) 🆕 Ibrahima Konate – Liverpool to Chelsea
There are whispers that Chelsea will offer £43million for Konate in the wake of Levi Colwill’s knee injury. Liverpool would prefer not to sell to a Premier League rival, but it would see them avoid losing the centre-back for nothing next summer. And they could immediately transfer the cash to Palace for Marc Guehi. So it makes a lot of sense, if they can just park the thought of aiding Chelsea.

17) 🔽 Carlos Baleba – Brighton to Manchester United
Baleba would make United a very passable football team. But United are dealing with Brighton, which isn’t easy even when they aren’t reluctant to sell. Apparently, their preference is to hold on to the midfielder for another year before banking another record fee. If United – and Baleba, if that is his preference – can force the issue, they should. But, knowing what we do about both clubs, we just can’t see it this summer. United are still trying, though, bless ’em.

16) 🆕 Savinho – Manchester City to Tottenham Hotspur
Apparently, Spurs are very keen on the City winger, though the reports that £43million might do the trick appear to be wide of the mark. Pep Guardiola seems to trust Savinho and we can’t imagine that selling the 21-year-old was part of the plan for this summer. Which makes us wonder what City might be up to…

15) 🔽 Gianluigi Donnarumma – PSG to Manchester United
The Italian goalkeeper is in the final 12 months of his contract and has said goodbye to the PSG fans after being ostracised by an unnamed person (it’s Luis Enrique). He looks destined for the Premier League, but United aren’t his most likely destination.

14) Jorgen Strand Larsen – Wolves to Newcastle
Larsen could be the next player to get the opportunity to snub Newcastle while they continue to tread on rakes. There have been whispers of the Toon’s interest in the striker throughout the summer, and Wolves could see an opportunity to milk their desperation. Nantes’ Matthis Abline is being eyed as a possible replacement should Newcastle come for Larsen.

13) 🆕 Rasmus Hojlund – Manchester United to AC Milan
Pre-Sesko, the noises coming from Hojlund suggested he wanted to stay at United. Then he watched the Sesko unveiling before staying on the bench for the entirety of the draw with Fiorentina, all of which seems to have opened his mind more to the idea of joining AC Milan. The obvious problem for United: Milan can’t afford the £40million being asked. Mercifully for them, it seems there is a queue starting to form in Italy, with Inter, Roma, Juve and Napoli all jostling for position.

12) 🔽 Harvey Elliott – Liverpool to Tottenham
Thomas Frank was, well, frank in admitting that Spurs will need a replacement for James Maddison after the playmaker was ruled out for much of the season with an ACL injury. This makes sense if the two clubs can make the numbers work. And Liverpool want that number to be at least £40million. RB Leipzig are keen. The Germans are unlikely to compete in a bidding war but they could offer a buy-back option which is said to be part of the conditions Liverpool have laid out.

11) Dango Ouattara – Bournemouth to Brentford
Apparently, the Bees are one of a few clubs to have been in touch about the 23-year-old, who has told Bournemouth that he wants to explore his options. With all due respect, though, we doubt he had Brentford in mind when he was thinking about taking the next step.

10) Alexander Isak – Newcastle to Liverpool
Isak is employing a scorched earth approach to getting out of Newcastle, leaving his legacy in tatters by refusing to play for the club again or reintegrate with Eddie Howe’s squad. It’s a ballsy approach – a d*ckish one too – and Isak needs to hope his desire is matched by Liverpool. We expect a move will happen because it’s in neither the player nor Newcastle’s interest to stay together, but the Toon need something they can present as a win, like a British transfer record fee up front. Not one made up of countless add-ons if Isak wins the Ballon d’Or or Grand National.

9) 🆕 Gianluigi Donnarumma – PSG to Manchester City
Donnarumma will definitely leave PSG. Where he ends up is less certain, but City are the current frontrunners…

8) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Eze is the Gunners’ next top target and the England star has, apparently, been telling his mates he’s moving to the Emirates, but Arsenal are yet to deliver on Palace’s clear demand for his £68million buy-out clause to be met. And their dithering could leave the door open for…

7) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Tottenham
Spurs’ need for attacking reinforcements is clear and multiple reports suggest they have opened talks about a move for Eze. They, though, do not intend to pay the amount necessary to trigger the England star’s buy-out clause. And the feeling is Eze would prefer Arsenal, which gives Spurs a brief window to strike a deal while their north London neighbours attempt to raise the necessary cash through sales.

6) 🔽 Tyler Dibling – Southampton to Everton
David Moyes has voiced his concerns about the Toffees’ lack of transfer activity, and his bosses have taken note. Dibling is reportedly the subject of a £35million-plus-£8million offer, but the Saints want more up front. Dibling has been withdrawn from some aspects of training and wasn’t included in Will Still’s squad for their Championship opener, though, so a deal cannot be far off. Could Jack Grealish’s arrival impact things?

5) 🔼 Yoane Wissa – Brentford to Newcastle
Everyone seems to be turning down Newcastle recently, but Wissa is one player who does want to join the Magpies. Strongly enough to go up against Brentford while they rebuff the Toon’s interest. At least until the offers reach around £40million. The best Newcastle have come up so far is £25million but an improved offer is expected this week. They would be wise not to waste theirs and Brentford’s time with another low-ball bid.

4) Xavi Simons – RB Leipzig to Chelsea
A Chelsea move appeals to Simons and the Blues are keen to make it happen. They are hoping Leipzig take back £40million-rated Christopher Nkunku as part of the deal.

3) 🔼 Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Chelsea
It’s ‘Chelsea or nowhere’ in Garnacho’s mind and, to be honest, we’re curious to see what ‘nowhere’ looks like. Of course, it won’t reach that stage because United want rid as much as the winger wants out. All of which Chelsea know and they will take their sweet time to get the best possible terms. United wanted at least £40million; we think they will settle for less as the deadline approaches.

2) 🔼 Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
Palace admit they may have to sell Guehi this summer rather than lose a £40million-rated asset for nothing in a year. Liverpool’s struggles in defence against the Eagles in the Community Shield ought to refocus their minds, especially with Chelsea pondering how to fill the void left by Levi Colwill’s injury; not so especially Manchester United’s ‘official approach’ for which huge fistfuls of salt are required. Alas, their interest has intensified and personal terms reportedly agreed.

1) 🔼 James McAtee – Manchester City to Nottingham Forest
It looks like Forest will win the race for McAtee, who has attracted interest from Germany. Reports suggest he’ll cost north of £20m having agreed personal terms with the City Ground club.

For their latest attempt at Premier League survival, Burnley have decided to build around some Chelsea cast-offs and some loanees whose deals were made permanent.

Spent a decent whack of money spent on Kevin Danso, Mathys Tel, Luka Vuskovic and Kota Takai before Thomas Frank even got a say. They had already dropped £50m on Dean Huijsen and £8.5m on a few weeks of Trent Alexander-Arnold before they agreed to sign man-child Franco Mastantuono for an awful lot of money. And then came Alvaro Carreras for another £43m.

3) Manchester United – £208.4m
The Red Devils are back near the top of this list after making Benjamin Sesko their third major summer signing after Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha. Ruben Amorim would ‘love’ two more…

headline: Man Utd ‘open to taking advantage’ as PSG ‘ready to move on’ £300,000-a-week superstar
body: Manchester United are considering a loan move for Paris Saint-Germain goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma, according to reports.
United have focused heavily on attacking reinforcements this summer, bringing in Matheus Cunha from Wolves, Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford and Benjamin Sesko from RB Leipzig.
Attention is now turning to other areas of Ruben Amorim’s squad, with goalkeeper reportedly identified as a position the club could strengthen if the right opportunity arises.
That opportunity could be presented by Donnarumma’s situation at PSG.

The Italy international was a key figure as Luis Enrique’s side won the Treble in 2024/25, keeping 17 clean sheets in 47 appearances. However, he has been left out of Wednesday’s squad for the UEFA Super Cup final against Tottenham Hotspur, after the signing of Lucas Chevalier, who is set to become first choice.
With Donnarumma entering the final year of his £300,000-a-week contract, PSG are ‘ready to move him on’ this summer, according to GiveMeSport.
United are understood to be ‘open to taking advantage’ of the situation with a loan offer, with a permanent deal ‘difficult to sanction’.
That stance is largely due to the presence of Andre Onana, with the club reluctant to have two high-earning goalkeepers on their books.
The Red Devils have explored potential exits for the Cameroon international, with interest from Saudi Arabia and AS Monaco earlier in the window, but no agreement has been reached.
The website suggests that United could look to move Onana out on loan, or even keep him to compete with Donnarumma if a financially viable loan arrangement with PSG can be struck.

PSG are not presently open to a loan move for the 26-year-old, preferring to secure a permanent sale. However, the Italian international is unhappy with how he has been treated, which has caught the attention of city rivals Manchester City.
Should any other club attempt to sign Donnarumma permanently, then United’s chances of landing him on loan should be dashed.
The report states:

Any loan deal for the former AC Milan stopper would mean PSG need to change their stance on a loan move though, as PSG are not currently open to that situation. However, the player is disappointed with the way he has been dealt with this summer and it’s possible he could push for an exit on his own terms.
United know what it’s like to get stuck with players they’ve been keen to move, and they could look to use that experience by negotiating terms with PSG that are favorable for all parties.

However, there is a threat that any loan move could fall apart if another club made an offer to sign the player permanently instead, as that is PSG’s preferred option. Premier League rivals Chelsea and Manchester City have both been linked with an interest in the 26-year-old, but sources understand nothing of substance has happened in either case so far.

headline: Man Utd flop’s ‘approval still pending’ after Red Devils ‘draft agreement’ with Euro giants
body: Manchester United have ‘reached a draft agreement’ to send Rasmus Hojlund to AC Milan, according to reports in Italy.
Hojlund is free to leave Old Trafford following the signing of Benjamin Sesko, who joined the club last week from RB Leipzig for around £73million.
Sesko will be Ruben Amorim’s first-choice centre-forward in 2025/26, opening the door for Hojlund to leave.
The Danish international joined United from Atalanta for a similar fee in 2022, but has failed to make his mark in the Premier League.
He only scored four times in the league last term as the Red Devils finished a shocking 15th place.
After landing wide forwards Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo, Amorim’s side set their sights on a new No.9, and now that Sesko has joined, the club are pushing to offload Hojlund.
Hojlund was an unused substitute in Saturday’s friendly draw against Fiorentina, which was reportedly a ‘clear message’ that he should look for a new club.
The 22-year-old seems determined to prove himself at Old Trafford and is reluctant to leave.
He said last month: “I am still very young, people sometimes forget that. I am only 22 years old. I have learned a lot, and I think that shows in my game.
“I have done very well so far during the pre-season…I want to stay here.
“Competition is fine with me. It sharpens me! I’m more than ready. I’m feeling sharp, so I’m welcoming everything that comes. I think it’s good with competition.”
But United want to get rid of the player and have reached a ‘draft agreement’ to loan him out to Milan, according to Italian website Calciomercato.
It’s claimed that the Serie A giants are also interested in signing Juventus striker Dusan Vlahovic, but know Hojlund will be ‘more affordable’.
Indeed, the United man is ‘the hottest prospect’ with a €4million net salary, compared to Vlahovic’s €12m per year.
Discussions are ongoing but the ‘draft agreement on the deal’s formula and figures’ is confirmed, with United agreeing to loan Hojlund out in a deal worth €6m.
A €40-45m option to buy will also be included, but ‘the player’s approval is still pending’.
It’s added, however, that ‘a transfer market meeting took place today’ (Tuesday) between Hojlund and the Red Devils hierarchy, with the club emphasising their desire for him to move.
Milan might have to move on to alternative targets, which include the more expensive Vlahovic and Paris Saint-Germain’s Goncalo Ramos.
As things stand, it’s likely the Rossoneri do move elsewhere, as Hojlund ‘isn’t yet 100% convinced about leaving, especially since he’s a huge Manchester United fan.’

headline: Man Utd star accused of delaying Milan transfer after ‘verbal agreement’ for exit is struck
body: Former AC Milan and Italy head coach Arrigo Sacchi doesn’t understand why Man Utd striker Rasmus Hojlund isn’t “on the first plane to Malpensa”.
The Red Devils are looking to offload some squad players, especially in attack, after bringing in Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Benjamin Sesko this summer.

Hojlund has been the subject of a lot of interest, especially from clubs in Italy, despite the striker hitting the back of the net on just four occasions for Man Utd in the Premier League last season.
Italian website Calciomercato recently revealed that Man Utd had ‘reached a verbal agreement’ with AC Milan over a £5.2m loan deal that will include an option to buy the Denmark international.

Transfer journalist Ben Jacobs revealed on Sunday that the Red Devils have told Hojlund that ‘he’ll need to leave to gain minutes this season’ while the striker had ‘reluctantly’ accepted that to be the case.

Jacobs wrote on X: ‘Rasmus Hojlund has now been directly told he’ll need to leave to gain minutes this season and is considering his options. Manchester United prefer to sell, but have not ruled out a loan. Milan prepared to meet #MUFC’s £40m valuation via a loan fee and buy option. Further talks took place yesterday.’

And ex-Italy head coach Sacchi is baffled why a deal is taking so long and insists the Man Utd striker should jump at the chance to move to Milan.
Sacchi told La Gazzetta dello Sport: “We’re not talking about van Basten, nor are we talking about one of the strongest centre-forwards in Europe at the moment. He’s a decent player, nothing more.
“I understand the desire of the Rossoneri directors given that there is a shortage of strikers. But it has to be one that wants to come to Italy, one that doesn’t throw a tantrum.
“I don’t understand his choice. If Milan calls you, you pack your bags and get on the first plane to Malpensa.
“Milan, in the world of football, is a mystical name. I, along with all the players who are brought in, would take a tour of the trophy room so that we understand where we have come.

“Of course, Manchester United is also a legendary team. But on the one hand, there is a club, Milan, which is offering you a permanent job, and on the other hand, there is a club that is doing everything to try and sell you. What would you choose?”
Former Man Utd defender Mikael Silvestre insists he “wouldn’t rush” into sending Hojlund out on loan without the necessary competition in the squad.
Silvestre told Hajper: “Marcus Rashford has gone and there are not a lot of strikers around, Joshua Zirkzee is a different type of striker that doesn’t make those runs in behind the defence.

“He is another type of player for certain games, certain opposition. But no, you need competition, need quality, so I wouldn’t rush into sending Rasmus Hojlund out on loan if Sesko signs. Absolutely not.”

However, transfer reporter Fabrizio Romano claims City have now reached out to the Parisians in the hope of bringing Donnarumma to the Etihad.

Despite having won the Champions League last summer, Donnarumma has been allowed to leave this summer with just 12 months left on his deal and no sign he will sign an extension. That fact was highlighted by PSG leaving him out of their squad to face Tottenham Hotspur in the UEFA Super Cup on Wednesday.

headline: Arsenal, Spurs, Newcastle and Leeds face rush to trigger transfer release clauses before deadline
body: Hugo Ekitike, Viktor Gyokeres and Benjamin Sesko have all been removed from the equation but some transfer release clauses expire well before the deadline.
This is an inexhaustive list of players with release clauses which could actually viably be triggered from summer 2025 onwards. We are talking sub-£100m, not your daft £1bn La Liga jobs.

Alex Remiro
The usual suspects have been linked in Aston Villa and Newcastle but Remiro has never played outside of Spain, has only been capped twice by the European champions and carries a hefty £60.4m price tag.

Diogo Costa
Manchester United have been linked with Portugal international keeper Costa before but Newcastle have been mentioned after missing out on James Trafford.
It doesn’t feel like Porto will hold out for the full £51.9m, nor that any club would pay it.

John Victor
The Club World Cup was a lovely shop window for the Botafogo keeper but West Ham had sudden cold feet – and were slammed for it – over an £8.6m move.

Edmond Tapsoba
Newcastle are said to have offered £50m for Bayer Leverkusen defender Tapsoba; it is unknown whether or not they realise it might take as much as £80m.

Castello Lukeba
An eclectic cast of Liverpool, Spurs, Bayern Munich and Manchester City have been mentioned in discussions over Lukeba’s future, with a suggestion that Leipzig might not necessarily hold out for the French centre-half’s entire £77.8m release clause.

Ousmane Diomande
Crystal Palace have already identified their replacement for Marc Guehi, whether the captain leaves this summer or not. But they will not be paying £69.1m for the Sporting centre-half if they do sign him.

Miguel Gutierrez
A whole host of clubs like the look of Girona left-back Gutierrez at £30.2m – he was once described as a ‘priority signing’ for Liverpool and Manchester United are known to be lurking – but any hopeful negotiators will have to deal with about 427 clauses Real Madrid still hold over him.

Jhon Lucumi
Aston Villa and Bournemouth are sniffing around Bologna defender Lucumi, with Roma also contemplating a move for the 26-year-old who will only come as cheap as £23.9m until July 10.

Enzo Boyomo
Aston Villa and Crystal Palace are known admirers of Osasuna centre-half Boyomo, who has been crucial for a side he only joined a year ago.
Boyomo stayed at Real Valladolid for just one campaign too before moving to Pamplona; whoever triggers his £21m release clause might expect to keep him for a little longer.

Kevin Lomonaco
“I really like the Premier League. It’s what I watch the most. I like West Ham,” should raise an absurd number of red flags within the departments of any and all clubs charged with scrutinising the character and even sanity of 23-year-old Lomonaco.
The centre-half has attracted interest from the Hammers, Crystal Palace, Sevilla and Wolfsburg in his £16.7m release clause.

Xavi Simons
It is believed that Simons has a release clause in his Leipzig contract worth around £70m but Chelsea are negotiating at a lower price point and Arsenal are contemplating turning the hijacking tables.

Eberechi Eze
Crystal Palace averted the potential crisis of having both Eze and Michael Olise’s release clauses triggered in the same summer but the fine print in the former’s deal has been reactivated in the summer. There is no shortage of potential suitors but still doubt that a £68m deal is worth it.
Suitors have until August 15 to decide. It is Arsenal v Spurs.

Samu Aghehowa
Another sign that Chelsea might have cracked something in the transfer code, Aghehowa was targeted for around £35m in what was basically a Conor Gallagher swap before the striker changed his surname, joined Porto and teased the sort of form which might attract £86.3m interest.
Newcastle would like him but not at that price.

Vangelis Pavlidis
It has been a strong summer for centre-forwards having release clauses triggered but Pavlidis is unlikely to follow Hugo Ekitike, Viktor Gyokeres and Benjamin Sesko.
Newcastle think £86.3m is a little too rich for their tastes.

Nico Williams
The bad news for Arsenal is that the Athletic Bilbao winger has extended his contract to 2035. The good news is that he still has a release clause, and it’s worth £82-86m. You’re still thinking about the bad news, aren’t you?

Moise Kean
Everton might not get involved but after scoring 23 goals in 42 games this season, Kean could repay the faith shown in him by Fiorentina with another big move. For two weeks from the start of July the Manchester United target is available for as little as £45m.

Bilal El Khannouss
One of few players to emerge from Leicester’s latest relegation mess can be rescued from the King Power Stadium for as little as £22.5m until August 15.
El Khannouss is on the radar of Leeds, Newcastle and Crystal Palace among others.

Andoni Iraola
Bournemouth quietly fell off towards the end of the season to bring their dream of European qualification combined with FA Cup glory crashing back down to reality. But they will not waver in their determination to extend Iraola’s contract – and perhaps even remove that £10m release clause. Spurs have at least removed themselves from the equation.

headline: Brighton boss Hurzeler insists no ‘fear’ over losing Man Utd target Carlos Baleba
body: Fabian Hurzeler insists he has no “fear” of losing key players with Carlos Baleba the latest high-profile name to be linked with a move away.
Manchester United reportedly put in an opening bid for the 21-year-old only to be told he has a £105m price tag on his head, but the Old Trafford club are said to be mulling over a second bid.
If Baleba does leave, he would be the latest in a long line of Brighton players to be sold on for big profits, and Seagulls boss Hurzeler said he had concern about losing key members of his squad.
“No chance. I don’t feel fear,” Hurzeler told the BBC.
“I’m not afraid of anything because the only thing we can do is be the best version we can be every day, work as hard as we can.
“All the other things we can’t influence, so we really have to focus on us.

“For sure, we can’t spend the money like the big teams, but one of our biggest values is togetherness. And if you stay together, if we try to push our limits and increase the boundaries, then I’m sure we can compete with the big teams.”

To Brighton’s credit, they have survived losing big players before, with the likes of Moises Caicedo, Marc Cucurella, Ben White and Alexis Mac Allister all moving on, with the club finishing no lower than 11th since 2022.
For those reasons, Hurzeler was confident that his team can compete this season, even with their most recent loss of Pedro to Chelsea for £60m.
“It’s not easy, but we proved last season that we are a very competitive team,” the league’s youngest manager said.

headline: Who will be the next Man Utd manager if Ruben Amorim is sacked?
body: Ruben Amorim lost the Europa League final to a historically bad Tottenham side and himself said he was willing to leave “without conversation or compensation” if he was not wanted by Manchester United.
In truth he will surely be given at least a bit of time after a summer to build a squad closer to something that suits his formation.
Still, though, just for fun: who could take over at Manchester United? We have the big names with the latest odds here…

10) Roberto De Zerbi
The current Marseille manager will remain high on any list of possible managers for any big Premier League club because he ‘knows the league’, doesn’t he?

6=) Zinedine Zidane
People keep trying to make Zinedine Zidane to United happen. It’s not going to happen.

6=) Unai Emery
Might be the one high-profile Premier League manager for whom the Man United job holds more appeal than Man City. He’s already had one crack at replacing a Big Six legend whose fingerprints are all over the club. At least with United he’s a good few steps removed from all that. But swapping what he’s got going at Villa for United would still be a questionable move.

6=) Marco Silva
Has done quietly brilliant things at Fulham, but would Manchester United settle for quietly brilliant things? They probably should, they definitely won’t.

5) Kieran McKenna
His agent played a blinder as reported interest from Manchester United and Chelsea led to a four-year contract at Ipswich that made him one of the best-paid managers in the Premier League. But would United fans really countenance the appointment of a relegated manager?

3=) Michael Carrick
Would ‘knows the club’ trump the fact that Carrick has not long been sacked by a Championship club? It didn’t work out brilliantly for Frank Lampard at Chelsea, but it remains a curiously beguiling CV booster even at the very heftiest of clubs.

3=) Mauricio Pochettino
Chelsea chose the path of abject stupidity and it appeared to leave the path clear for United to pounce on a manager they had coveted back in his Tottenham days. They decided to eschew that option in favour of sticking with what’s been working so very well for them.

Any second thoughts United might have on that bit of decision-making are for now pretty much futile, with Pochettino having taken the USA job. That surely puts him out of contention for anything else until next summer and a (mostly) home World Cup.

1=) Gareth Southgate
Very strongly linked with the Manchester United job last summer after somehow taking England to another European final. He would not be a popular appointment, but the good news for United fans is that it won’t happen.

Southgate has been pretty clear about feeling mighty comfortable about never taking another managerial job. That hasn’t stopped him being described as a “master of manipulation” and being tipped for the big job, mind.

1=) Oliver Glasner
That FA Cup win with Crystal Palace has taken the Austrian high up all the lists, and now right to the very top of the silliest of all of them with Spurs off the table for at least the next few months.
